Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I stood at the corner, clutching my bag, mind racing. My little brother darted ahead, his eyes fixed on the ice cream truck across the street. He didn’t even glance at the traffic. My heart leapt—Mom always said to watch out for him, to make sure he was safe. But I was already late, and today was my only chance to swing by home and grab my ID before work. If I missed it, I might not be able to vote tomorrow. The polls would still be open, but I wouldn’t have another break to get my ID. I could see the cars speeding by, my brother’s foot hovering at the curb. I felt torn in two—my responsibility as his sibling pulling me one way, my duty as a voter tugging the other. My chest tightened as I hesitated, caught between shouting his name and sprinting for the bus that would take me home.
